title: N06-1037

sentences.text: This paper proposes to use a convolution kernel over parse trees to model syntactic structure information for relation extraction .
Our study reveals that the syntactic structure features embedded in a parse tree are very effective for relation extraction and these features can be well captured by the convolution tree kernel .

Evaluation on the ACE 2003 corpus shows that the convolution kernel over parse trees can achieve comparable performance with the previous best-reported feature-based methods on the 24 ACE relation subtypes .
It also shows that our method significantly outperforms the previous two dependency tree kernels on the 5 ACE relation major types .

summary: This paper proposes to use a convolution kernel over parse trees to model syntactic structure information for relation extraction . Our study reveals that the syntactic structure features embedded in a parse tree are very effective for relation extraction and these features can be well captured by the convolution tree kernel . Evaluation on the ACE 2003 corpus shows that the convolution kernel over parse trees can achieve comparable performance with the previous best-reported feature-based methods on the 24 ACE relation subtypes . It also shows that our method significantly outperforms the previous two dependency tree kernels on the 5 ACE relation major types .

Predicate-proposes_to_use.label: proposes to use
Predicate-proposes_to_use.description: The predicate 'proposes to use' indicates a plan or intention to employ a particular method, technique, or tool (object), as suggested by the subject. It implies that the subject has considered and recommends using the object for a specific purpose.

Predicate-model.label: model
Predicate-model.description: The predicate 'model' represents a conceptual representation or abstraction of its subject that captures essential characteristics and patterns from its object. It implies a process of learning, inference, or generalization that enables the subject to capture relevant information about the object.

Predicate-proposes_to_use_a_convolution_.label: proposes to use a convolution kernel over parse trees
Predicate-proposes_to_use_a_convolution_.description: To employ a specific machine learning technique that leverages the structural properties of natural language text by applying convolutional operations over parse trees, with the goal of extracting meaningful information or relationships.

Predicate-reveals_that_the_syntactic_str.label: reveals that the syntactic structure features embedded in a parse tree are very effective for relation extraction and these features can be well captured by
Predicate-reveals_that_the_syntactic_str.description: The predicate 'reveals' connects the subject to an explanation or demonstration of how a particular set of syntactic structure features embedded in a parse tree can be effective for relation extraction, and further indicates that these features can be well captured by a specific method or technique.

Predicate-outperforms.label: outperforms
Predicate-outperforms.description: Indicates that the subject has a superior performance or achievement compared to the object. The predicate suggests a competitive relationship between the subject and object, implying that the subject's performance is better than the object's.

Predicate-proposes.label: proposes
Predicate-proposes.description: To propose something means to suggest or recommend it as a solution, idea, or plan. The predicate 'proposes' indicates that the subject (a person, entity, or thing) offers or presents an object (an idea, concept, proposal, etc.) for consideration, discussion, or implementation.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is a specific instance or example of a more general concept or category represented by the object. The relationship between the subject and object is one of instantiation, where the subject is a particular manifestation or realization of the broader concept denoted by the object.
